keyTakeAways: Rodrigo Paz won the presidential election in Bolivia with 54% of the vote, defeating former president Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga, who received 45%.
Paz, a centrist senator with no prior national prominence, rose to prominence due to public frustration with 20 years of Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) rule and Bolivia's economic crisis.
Paz’s victory reflects a significant political shift, with working-class and rural voters rejecting MAS’s economic policies and opting for a centrist alternative that promises gradual reforms.
Paz plans to end the fixed exchange rate, phase out fuel subsidies, and reduce public investment, but will maintain MAS-style social benefits to avoid economic shock.
Bolivia faces a deep economic crisis with 23% year-on-year inflation, fuel shortages, and a lack of foreign currency reserves, which Paz must address in his first months in office.
Paz has rejected reliance on the International Monetary Fund, instead pledging to restore confidence through anti-corruption measures and fiscal discipline.
Despite his popularity, Paz’s economic plans have drawn criticism for being vague and potentially unsustainable, especially given public fear of past IMF interventions.
The election outcome signals a realignment in Bolivia’s political landscape, moving away from socialist governance toward a more centrist, economically cautious path.
Paz’s victory represents a broader trend of political disillusionment with long-standing parties and a desire for change in a nation facing severe economic hardship.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Rodrigo Paz, a centrist senator with no prior national prominence, has won Bolivia’s presidential election with 54% of the vote, defeating former president Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga. The victory reflects widespread public frustration with 20 years of Movement Toward Socialism (MAS) rule and a severe economic crisis marked by inflation, fuel shortages, and a dollar shortage. Paz, supported by working-class and rural voters, promises gradual economic reforms, including ending the fixed exchange rate and cutting fuel subsidies, while maintaining MAS-style social benefits to avoid a recession. Despite his popularity, his economic plans have drawn criticism for being vague. Paz’s win marks a significant political shift, signaling a move away from socialist governance toward a more centrist, economically cautious path. Bolivia now faces a critical challenge in restoring foreign currency reserves, ensuring fuel imports, and rebuilding public trust—without relying on the International Monetary Fund.
title: Rodrigo Paz Wins Bolivia’s Presidential Election Amid Economic Crisis and Political Shift
